awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Using Template Models to Identify Exoskeleton User Intent
awd_abstract_narration:
Exoskeletons have great potential to restore mobility and improve quality of life for individuals with locomotor impairments due to neurotrauma such as spinal cord injury (SCI) and stroke. For several years, clinical exoskeleton use has accelerated gait retraining by enabling patients to take more steps per session, practice more repeatable gait patterns, and have their progress more closely monitored. Today, the technology has matured to the point that multiple systems with FDA approval are commercially available. Still, broader exoskeleton adoption, both in the clinic and for personal use, is needed for the technology to achieve its full potential to impact daily life. The key barrier to such adoption is the lack of a fluent and transparent interface to determine how the user intends to move in conjunction with the exoskeleton. This project seeks to enable exoskeleton use in the diverse scenarios of daily life by developing a robust approach to determine a user's intent. Since the fundamental mechanics of walking are truly universal, the approach is to leverage relatively simple template models of walking that encode these mechanics within algorithms that more reliably identify user intent. Activities of interest include starting from rest, changing walking speed, direction, and cadence, stair ascent/descent, and stopping. The models will be applied to both healthy subjects and individuals with spinal cord injury to identify commonality and critical differences. Beyond the benefits to exoskeleton end-users, the project will facilitate outreach to both K-12 teachers and middle school students to promote education in the STEM disciplines by highlighting how engineering can directly improve quality of life. 

This project aims to improve human machine interface technologies for lower-body exoskeletons by using simple template models of locomotion to more effectively capture user intent. In most existing approaches, mapping sensor data to the user's state/activity is treated as a black-box pattern recognition problem. In contrast, reduced order models or templates are low-dimensional dynamical systems that capture the fundamental mechanics of walking, upon which more complex behaviors play out. The project will investigate physics-based template models to augment inference of exoskeleton user intent for small changes to nominal walking gait (speed, direction, and cadence). Leveraging bio-inspired template control algorithms, extended Kalman filtering and non-parameteric Bayesian approaches will be investigated to solve a stochastic intent observer problem. Next, the work will be extended to detect transitions in user intent for starting, stopping, and gait progression to/from stairs. Throughout, parallel analysis will study customization of the methodology, including the use of entirely different template models, for exoskeleton users with locomotor impairments. Data-driven Floquet analysis will be applied for translation of data from healthy users to augment intent recognition in users with spinal cord injury. Experiments with the new intent recognition will be incorporated into the control system of an FDA-approved exoskeleton that will be used to assess recognition delay and generalization performance of the methods relative to existing techniques. These experiments will be conducted first with healthy subjects and subsequently with individuals with incomplete spinal cord injury. Ultimately, the project has the potential to improve the impact of exoskeletons in areas spanning rehabilitation, search-and-rescue, military, and industrial applications by more effectively capturing user intent.

por.por_cntn:
Lower-limb exoskeletons have great potential to restore mobility and improve quality of life for individuals with locomotor impairments due to neurotrauma such as spinal cord injury and stroke. Expanded regulatory approval and commercial availability have led to some growth in clinical exoskeleton use for gait retraining, but critical barriers still exist. The main barrier to broader adoption, both in the clinic and for personal use, is the absence of fluent and transparent human-machine interfaces that capture user intent. This research demonstrated how sensors onboard all commercially available lower-limb exoskeletons provide rich information from which user intent can be inferred.

The research team demonstrated that both able-bodied exoskeleton users and users with spinal cord injury convey their intent to change walking speed in ways that can be quantified by measurement of the exoskeleton joint angles and commanded motor currents. These measurements are already available to the controllers in all commercially available exoskeletons. The research showed that the values of 8 quantities (2 hip angles, 2 knee angles, 2 hip motor currents, and 2 knee motor currents) at each instant in the user’s cycle of walking can be compared to their values from reference data collected across a range of speeds. A multivariable statistical tool, the Mahalanobis distance, takes into account the typical variability in these 8 quantities to return a likelihood that the user desires to change speed. The work also demonstrated the tradeoff between accurately identifying such changes in intended speed and the time delay associated with the identification. Increasing accuracy leads to greater time delay, but even for users with spinal cord injury, for whom time delay was greater, identification of a speed change was reliably achieved in less than one stride. The efficiency of the approach with respect to the amount of data required was studied with able-bodied subjects considering only the joint angle data. Accuracy reached 87% with just 5 minutes of training data, suggesting that user-specific training is feasible for time-restrictive applications such as physical therapy.

Additional work reduced the duration of data collection required for accurate user intent identification for individuals with spinal cord injury by bootstrapping the analysis using data from able-bodied individuals. The able-bodied data was transformed to match characteristics of smaller data sets (only 8-12 steps) collected from each individual with spinal cord injury. The model of gait speed intent for the individual was then built on this larger, but transformed data set. Results showed improved accuracy in identifying the intent of an exoskeleton user with spinal cord injury to change speed, while requiring substantially less of that individual’s own training data. Finally, the project showed how the identified intent to change speed could be incorporated to alter the prescribed gait trajectories of the exoskeleton. This was framed as an optimal control problem with the user’s desired walking speed as the input. The results demonstrate the tradeoff between faithfully achieving the user’s intent and minimizing the overall effort required from the exoskeleton. 

The research findings were widely disseminated via peer-reviewed journal articles and conference papers and presentations. One of the five graduate students who contributed to the project, Dr. Taylor Higgins, is working to extend the results as she begins her own independent research laboratory as a tenure-track faculty member within the Florida A&M University – Florida State University College of Engineering. Two of the five graduate students are using their Ph.D. training in a robotics startup company, and a third is working in the research arm of a large U.S. auto manufacturer. The fifth graduate student is still completing his Ph.D. in the area of human-robot interaction. Of the six undergraduates who worked on the project, half went on to graduate school in mechanical engineering, while the other half are working in engineering positions in industry, one as the chief technology officer and founder of a startup. Seven of these eleven trained students come from groups traditionally underrepresented in engineering. These students also contributed to and/or participated in a range of outreach activities that included a two-day workshop with hardware demos for local K-12 teachers as part of the Teachers as Scholars program and semiannual presentations with demos to local middle school students through the STARBASE Academy.
